option.value: Module 3: AWR-341 IED Awareness and Safety Procedures

string_table.string: Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

search.slidetext: welcome select next to continue. delivery mechanisms and concealment tactics unattended and suspicious items response procedures
delivery mechanisms for ieds select next to continue. dzhokhar tsarnaev belt collar bomb fbi evidence photograph from the underwear bomber
concealment and containers select next to continue. ramzi yousef
staying alert to surroundings select next to continue.
rain select the four buttons to find out more. select next to continue. select next to continue select next to continue
rain: recognize unattended select next to continue. suspicious unknown origin job aid job aid job aid

question 1: janice is in a team meeting in the conference room when a co-worker alerts the team of a possible bomb in the break room. what should janice do? 1. leave the building with her co-workers and ensure security has been notified. 1. leave the building with her co-workers and ensure security has been notified. 1. leave the building with her co-workers and ensure security has been notified. 1. leave the building with her co-workers and ensure security has been notified. 1. leave the building with her co-workers and ensure security has been notified. 1. leave the building with her co-workers and ensure security has been notified. 2. go back to her desk to get her phone and laptop and then leave the building with her co-workers. 2. go back to her desk to get her phone and laptop and then leave the building with her co-workers. 2. go back to her desk to get her phone and laptop and then leave the building with her co-workers. 2. go back to her desk to get her phone and laptop and then leave the building with her co-workers. 2. go back to her desk to get her phone and laptop and then leave the building with her co-workers. 2. go back to her desk to get her phone and laptop and then leave the building with her co-workers. knowledge check complete the knowledge check, then select next to continue. danger safety correct! janice needs to get to safety as quickly as possible. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct incorrect sorry, that’s not right. because the device could be timed, it’s better if janice gets to safety as quickly as possible. continue continue continue continue continue continue submit submit submit submit
rain: recognize select next to continue.

question 2: derick notices an unattended backpack as he is walking through the entrance of a baseball stadium. he has started to move away and warn others to do the same. he knows he needs to alert security or the police. what should derick do? 1. attempt to open the bag and find out who the owner is. 1. attempt to open the bag and find out who the owner is. 1. attempt to open the bag and find out who the owner is. 1. attempt to open the bag and find out who the owner is. 1. attempt to open the bag and find out who the owner is. 1. attempt to open the bag and find out who the owner is. 2. ask loudly in the immediate area “is this your bag?” then if no-one answers contact the stadium security. 2. ask loudly in the immediate area “is this your bag?” then if no-one answers contact the stadium security. 2. ask loudly in the immediate area “is this your bag?” then if no-one answers contact the stadium security. 2. ask loudly in the immediate area “is this your bag?” then if no-one answers contact the stadium security. 2. ask loudly in the immediate area “is this your bag?” then if no-one answers contact the stadium security. 2. ask loudly in the immediate area “is this your bag?” then if no-one answers contact the stadium security. knowledge check complete the knowledge check, then select next to continue. danger safety yes, that is correct! someone could have easily misplaced their bag, and nothing about the situation is immediately suspicious. if derick can’t find an owner, however, he should report the situation to security so that they can continue the investigation. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct incorrect sorry, that is not the best answer. if the item is unattended, he should first exhaust all means to identify the owner. if an owner is not found, he should notify security. continue continue continue continue continue continue submit submit submit submit

select next to continue rain: notify ? remember and report the details! who was involved? what happened? where and when it happened? special hazards? indicators of the type of hazard? protective measures taken? facilities and locations affected? location and appearance of the device or item? 100 feet
select exit to return to the main course menu rain: avoid unattended and suspicious item guidance unattended and suspicious item guidance unattended and suspicious item guidance
select next to continue rain: isolate stand off card stand off card stand off card

identifying potentially suspicious items select suspicious items, then select next to continue. a cake may seem out of context, unless this office space belongs to the office manager or individual responsible for remembering and celebrating staff birthdays. two trash cans can appear odd, unless the cleaning crew often moves around trash cans during their rotation. luggage might be a suspicious item, unless the owner of this cubicle is heading to the airport for vacation after work today. you haven’t viewed all of the content on this slide. press continue if you would like to view the remaining content or next to view the next slide. continue continue continue continue continue continue

question 3: greg, a pipeline worker, reports to work and sees something odd duct-taped to one of the critical valves in his area. he does not recognize the item and it looks suspicious. what actions should he take? 1. cut the tapped object off the valve and take it to his plant supervisor to see what it is. 1. cut the tapped object off the valve and take it to his plant supervisor to see what it is. 1. cut the tapped object off the valve and take it to his plant supervisor to see what it is. 1. cut the tapped object off the valve and take it to his plant supervisor to see what it is. 1. cut the tapped object off the valve and take it to his plant supervisor to see what it is. 1. cut the tapped object off the valve and take it to his plant supervisor to see what it is. 2. ask his co-workers if they placed the item, if they all say “no” then evacuate the immediate area to 300 feet, seek shelter, and inform his supervisors or security. 2. ask his co-workers if they placed the item, if they all say “no” then evacuate the immediate area to 300 feet, seek shelter, and inform his supervisors or security. 2. ask his co-workers if they placed the item, if they all say “no” then evacuate the immediate area to 300 feet, seek shelter, and inform his supervisors or security. 2. ask his co-workers if they placed the item, if they all say “no” then evacuate the immediate area to 300 feet, seek shelter, and inform his supervisors or security. 2. ask his co-workers if they placed the item, if they all say “no” then evacuate the immediate area to 300 feet, seek shelter, and inform his supervisors or security. 2. ask his co-workers if they placed the item, if they all say “no” then evacuate the immediate area to 300 feet, seek shelter, and inform his supervisors or security. knowledge check complete the knowledge check, then select next to continue. danger safety good work! greg has noticed a suspicious item and once he asks his co-workers about it, they should all evacuate to a safe location and inform the proper authorities. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct incorrect sorry, that is not the best answer. greg thinks this item taped to critical infrastructure is suspicious, and there is always the possibility that it is an ied that will go off when touched. you should never touch a suspicious item. continue continue continue continue continue continue submit submit submit submit
summary select exit to return to the course menu select exit to return to the main course menu

help menu link - provides access to the course outline resources link - contains additional websites and documents for you to reference as you complete the course glossary link - contains definitions of key terms used in this course exit link - allows you to leave the module closed captioning (cc) button - allows you to toggle on and off closed captioning for the narration speaker button - allows you to toggle on and off the audio associated with the course play/pause button - allows you to play and pause the audio and on-screen visuals replay button - allows you to restart the current on-screen audio and visuals previous button - allows you to return to the previous screen in the course next button - allows you to advance to the next screen in the course red x icons - allow you to close pop-ups

glossary blast effect - when an explosive detonates, releasing a tremendous amount of energy commercial/military explosives - manufactured explosives that have standardized chemical and explosive properties explosives - also called the main charge, consists of either an explosive or combustible material fragmentation effect - when a bomb explodes and high-velocity fragments are thrown in all directions homemade explosive (hme) - explosives created by combining common household ingredients to create a combustible material improvised explosive device (ied) - a device placed or fabricated in an improvised manner incorporating destructive, lethal, noxious, pyrotechnic, or incendiary chemicals and designed to destroy, incapacitate, harass, or distract initiator - the first explosive in the explosive train of an ied that starts the actual explosive event pies - power source, initiator, explosives, switch placed ied - an ied positioned at the target prior to detonation power source - an internal energy source that stores or releases electrical, mechanical, or chemical energy to initiate an ied projected ied - an ied that is thrown or propelled towards an intended target rain - an acronym for what to do if you encounter a suspected ied; it stands for recognize, avoid, isolate, notify suspicious item - an item, package, or vehicle that indicates, in some way, that it may contain an explosive device or some other hazard switch - the part of an ied that arms and fires sequences of the ied thermal effect - the heat or fireball created during an explosion unattended item - an item, package, or vehicle of unknown origin without an identified owner vehicle-born ied - an ied contained within a vehicle and delivered to the target by the vehicle worn ied - an ied delivered to its target, worn by either a bomber or victim

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: DHS Office for Bombing Prevention (OBP) Website http://www.dhs.gov/obp
DHS If You See Something, Say Something Website http://www.dhs.gov/see-something-say-something/about-campaign
DHS Bomb Threat Management Plan Checklist
Unattended and Suspicious Items Guidance and RAIN Handout

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Welcome to the IED Awareness and Safety Procedures course. An improvised explosive device, or IED, is a device placed or fabricated in an improvised manner incorporating destructive, lethal, noxious, pyrotechnic, or incendiary chemicals and designed to destroy, incapacitate, harass, or distract.

This course will teach you how to Identify the purpose, resulting effects, and components of improvised explosive devices,

Describe how to respond to an unattended or suspicious item, and

Explain the proper agency procedures for responding to an unattended or suspicious item.

For information on how to navigate this course, select the “Navigation Tutorial” button in the top right corner of the screen, or select Next to start the course.

In a recent month, there were a calculated 233 bomb incidents nationwide. Ninety-five of these were bomb threats; 59 were suspicious items; and 44 were incidents in which bomb squads rendered safe the IEDs and explosive materials.

Since bomb incidents are a part of our world, it is important for each individual to have an understanding of what IEDs are, how they are constructed, and how to safely respond to them.

This training is a vital first step for empowering agency staff to identify potential threats, alert the appropriate authorities, and follow safety procedures.

Chaos erupts in an IED situation. That’s why it’s imperative to know how to respond to an IED threat-before the threat occurs. There are basic procedures that every person should follow, as well as additional tasks for those in law enforcement.

Select the Boston Bombing button to link to a video from AP Reporter Jay Lindsay about his coverage of the bombing and the confusion that occurred.

Chaos erupts in an IED situation. That’s why it’s imperative to know how to respond to an IED threat-before the threat occurs. There are basic procedures that every person should follow, as well as additional tasks for those in law enforcement.

Select the Boston Bombing button to link to a video from AP Reporter Jay Lindsay about his coverage of the bombing and the confusion that occurred.

Now that you understand why it is important to learn about IEDs, proceed to the next module to learn why bombers use IEDs, and the results, components, and explosive of effects IEDs.

Later in the course, you will learn how to safely respond to unattended and suspicious items.
